title: Pakistani Army Tells US It Wants Recognition for Fighting Terror, Not Money
body:
ISLAMABAD - The head of Pakistan's armed forces, Javed Bajwa, told the United States Ambassador David Hale that Islamabad is not looking for financial aid but recognition for its contributions in battling terrorism in the region.

"We are not looking for any material or financial assistance from US but trust, understanding and acknowledgment of our contributions," Bajwa said, according to a statement released by the army's media wing, ISPR.

The meeting occurred barely 24 hours after US President Donald Trump warned Islamabad that it had a lot to lose if it kept harboring terrorists and that the alliance between the two countries would not last long if this continued.

"We have been paying Pakistan billions and billions of dollars at the same time they are housing the very terrorists that we are fighting. That will have to change and that will change immediately," Trump had said Tuesday following the announcement of a new policy towards Afghanistan, including an increase in ground troops.

During his meeting with Hale, Bajwa said that Pakistan will continue to do everything possible to bring peace to Afghanistan, "not to appease anyone but in line with our national interest and national policy," according to the ISPR statement.

On Tuesday night, Pakistan's Foreign Ministry, in its first official statement after Trump's speech, had expressed its disappointment with the US and stressed that it would not allow its territory to be used against other countries.

The army chief considered the collaboration between all the parties involved were crucial in order to bring an end to the war in Afghanistan.

Over the years, Kabul and Washington have accused Islamabad of allegedly giving refuge to insurgent groups on Pakistani soil, such as the Taliban's Haqqani network, which carries out attacks against US and Afghan troops.

Pakistan has repeatedly denied giving shelter to terrorist groups or differentiating between the "good Taliban" - those that do not pose a threat to the country - and the "bad Taliban" - those that carry out attacks against the state of Pakistan.

title: Top US Officials Urge Taliban to Quit Arms and End Afghan War
body:
KABUL - The commander of United States Forces and NATO in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson and US Ambassador Hugo Llorens Thursday urged the Taliban to lay down arms and end the war.

The rebels were unlikely to win against America's new strategy on Afghanistan and should join the peace process, Nicholson said in Kabul at a joint press conference with Llorens after President Donald Trump Monday committed to an open-ended involvement of the US in the Afghan conflict, including sending more troops to the conflict-torn country.

Nicholson called the Taliban "a criminal organization," who were more "interested in profits from drugs and kidnappings," for which "90 percent of the people of Afghanistan believe a return to Taliban rule would be bad for the country."

"The Taliban have a simple choice: stop fighting against your countrymen. Stop killing innocent civilians. Stop bringing hardship and misery," said Nicholson.

"We must maintain pressure on the Taliban to join a peace process with the Afghan government to end the war in Afghanistan," Llorens had said.

Meanwhile, following Trump's announcement, the Taliban warned the US that if it did not withdraw from the country, Afghanistan will become "the 21st-century graveyard for the American empire."

The deployment of new troops, which could be around 4,000 soldiers, although Trump is yet to specify the exact number, would add to the 8,400 US soldiers already stationed in the country.

Trump's decision marks a complete shift from the policy of former president Barack Obama's administration (2009-2017), which after having deployed around 100,000 soldiers in Afghanistan in 2010, had opted for a phased withdrawal of troops.

Both Nicholson and Llorens also urged Pakistan to stop sheltering the Taliban on its territory.

"The dialogue with Pakistan will be done in private and has already started," Nicholson said, adding that elimination of Taliban safe havens was key to the success of the new policy.

According to the Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction report released this month, the war in Afghanistan is stagnant with insurgents controlling 40 percent of the country.
